setup.text: When you hear 'objects launched into space', what interests you most?

options.text: Stories and impacts on daily life

tech_act1.text: Looking at data up to 2019, was the launch rate stable or steadily growing?

tech_act2_stable.text: In 2020, do you see it as a statistical anomaly or a new trend?
ctas: Think about how to anticipate sudden breaks in seemingly static markets.

tech_act2_growing.text: In 2020, do you see it as a statistical anomaly or a new trend?
ctas: Reflect on how to distinguish between linear and exponential growth in forecasting models.

tech_act3_anomaly.text: Who drove the growth after 2020: governments, private companies, or both?
ctas: Evaluate how algorithms can detect structural changes rather than discard them as noise.

tech_act3_trend.text: Who drove the growth after 2020: governments, private companies, or both?
ctas: Ask yourself: what weak signals are you monitoring to catch emerging trends?
Consider how public policies can influence your technological scenarios.
Think about how private innovation can reshape business models within years.
Ask: what strategic partnerships could accelerate your projects, as in space exploration?

gen_act1.text: Until 2019, was space filling up slowly or quickly?

gen_act2_slow.text: Was the 2020 boom an isolated case or the beginning of a new space era?
ctas: Slow changes can become revolutions without us noticing.

gen_act2_fast.text: Was the 2020 boom an isolated case or the beginning of a new space era?
ctas: We often overestimate a trend without imagining how much bigger it can become.

gen_act3_isolated.text: Who pushed the new space race more: governments or private companies?
ctas: Look around: which sudden jumps are actually deep transformations?
